concepts.name: Chronotype
concepts.description: A person's natural tendency to sleep at a particular time, categorized as morning (morning-type) or evening (evening-type). In this study, it is a key biological variable influencing sleep-wake patterns and memory performance.

concepts.name: Sleep-Wake Cycle
concepts.description: The daily pattern of sleep and wakefulness regulated by circadian rhythms. The study links disruptions in this cycle—particularly in night types—to impaired memory function.

concepts.name: Subjective Time Experience
concepts.description: An individual's personal perception of time, including feelings of time pressure, time dilation, or boredom. This study identifies it as a critical psychological mediator in memory performance.

concepts.name: Retrospective Memory
concepts.description: The ability to recall past events or information. The study assesses this using self-report questionnaires to evaluate memory accuracy and failure rates.

concepts.name: Prospective Memory
concepts.description: The ability to remember to perform a planned action in the future. Measured via the PRMQ, it is a core outcome variable in the study's analysis.

concepts.name: Memory Failure
concepts.description: The occurrence of errors in recalling past events (retrospective) or executing future intentions (prospective). The study identifies it as the primary dependent variable linked to chronotype and time perception.

concepts.name: Time Pressure
concepts.description: A subjective feeling of having insufficient time to complete tasks. The study shows it negatively correlates with memory performance and mediates the effect of chronotype.

concepts.name: Time Expansion
concepts.description: The perceptual distortion where time feels longer than it objectively is, often associated with boredom or monotony. This study links it to poorer memory outcomes.

concepts.name: Sleep Quality
concepts.description: A multidimensional construct reflecting the depth, continuity, and restfulness of sleep. Assessed via the MSQ, it is a key predictor of memory function in night types.

concepts.name: Circadian Disruption
concepts.description: Misalignment between internal biological rhythms and external environmental cues, particularly sleep timing. The study links it to increased memory errors in night types.

concepts.name: Attentional Resources
concepts.description: Cognitive capacity available for processing information. The proposed model suggests that chronotype and time perception affect memory via attentional depletion.

concepts.name: Arousal State
concepts.description: Level of physiological and mental alertness. The study posits that arousal mediates the relationship between chronotype and memory, especially during non-optimal times of day.

concepts.name: Mediation Model
concepts.description: A statistical framework used to test whether an intermediate variable (e.g., time perception) explains the relationship between an independent variable (chronotype) and a dependent variable (memory). Central to the study's theoretical contribution.

concepts.name: Integrated Biopsychological Model
concepts.description: A novel theoretical framework proposed by the authors that integrates biological (chronotype), physiological (arousal), and psychological (time perception) factors in memory functioning.

concepts.name: Self-Report Bias
concepts.description: Systematic error in data due to subjective interpretation or recall limitations in questionnaire responses. A key limitation acknowledged in the study.

concepts.name: Cross-Sectional Design
concepts.description: A research design that collects data at a single point in time, limiting causal inference. The study's design is explicitly described as cross-sectional.

concepts.name: Sleep-Wake Misalignment
concepts.description: A condition where sleep timing is inconsistent with social or biological demands, common in night types. The study links it to memory deficits via arousal and time perception.

concepts.name: Boredom Perception
concepts.description: A subjective state of disengagement or lack of stimulation, measured as part of time experience. The study finds it correlates with memory failure in night types.

concepts.name: Chronotype-Performance Link
concepts.description: The relationship between individual differences in circadian preference and cognitive performance. The study provides empirical evidence for this link via memory outcomes.

concepts.name: Objective vs Subjective Sleep
concepts.description: The distinction between measured (e.g., polysomnography) and self-reported sleep quality. The study relies solely on subjective measures, a noted limitation.

concepts.name: Non-Cognitive Factors in Memory
concepts.description: Psychological and physiological variables unrelated to core cognitive processes that influence memory. The study emphasizes these as underappreciated contributors.

concepts.name: Temporal Distortion
concepts.description: A perceptual phenomenon where time is experienced inaccurately, such as feeling time drags. The study identifies it as a mediator in memory failure.

concepts.name: Workday-Weekend Sleep Pattern
concepts.description: Differences in sleep timing between weekdays and weekends, a common behavior in night types. The study collects this via self-report to assess sleep regularity.

concepts.name: Predictive Validity
concepts.description: The extent to which a measure (e.g., rMEQ) can predict an outcome (e.g., memory errors). The study evaluates this through regression and mediation models.

concepts.name: Psychological Mediation
concepts.description: The process by which a psychological variable (e.g., time pressure) explains the relationship between two other variables (e.g., chronotype and memory). Core to the study's model.

concepts.name: Biological Rhythms
concepts.description: Endogenous cycles (e.g., circadian rhythms) that regulate physiological and behavioral processes. The study centers on their role in memory via sleep and arousal.

concepts.name: Cognitive Load
concepts.description: The amount of mental effort required to perform a task. Though not directly measured, the study implies that time pressure increases cognitive load, impairing memory.

concepts.name: Memory Monitoring
concepts.description: The ability to track and evaluate one’s own memory performance. The study’s self-report measures may reflect this, though it is not explicitly tested.

concepts.name: Daytime Sleepiness
concepts.description: A state of drowsiness during waking hours, often linked to poor sleep quality. The study implies it as a potential mechanism via arousal disruption.

concepts.name: Temporal Awareness
concepts.description: The conscious perception of the passage of time, a component of subjective time experience. The study uses it to explain memory variability.

concepts.name: Behavioral Consistency
concepts.description: The regularity of sleep-wake patterns across days. The study notes irregularity in night types as a predictor of memory issues.

concepts.name: Self-Regulation Failure
concepts.description: Inability to manage time, attention, or behavior effectively. The study suggests this may underlie memory errors in night types with poor time perception.

concepts.name: Causal Inference Limitation
concepts.description: The inability to establish cause-and-effect relationships from cross-sectional data. A key methodological constraint acknowledged by the authors.

concepts.name: Gender Imbalance
concepts.description: Overrepresentation of females in the sample (73%), which may affect generalizability of findings to male populations.

concepts.name: Psychosocial Confounders
concepts.description: Unmeasured variables such as stress, depression, or medication use that may influence both sleep and memory. The study admits these were not controlled.

concepts.name: Subjective Sleep Quality
concepts.description: An individual’s personal evaluation of their sleep, assessed via the MSQ. A key predictor in the regression models.

concepts.name: Time Perception Distortion
concepts.description: A misjudgment of time duration or flow, linked to attentional lapses. The study treats it as a mediator in the chronotype-memory pathway.

concepts.name: Arousal-Attention Mechanism
concepts.description: A proposed neurocognitive pathway where biological rhythms affect alertness, which in turn influences attention and memory. Central to the integrated model.

concepts.name: Prospective Memory Deficit
concepts.description: Failure to execute intended actions in the future, a key outcome in the study. Linked to chronotype and time perception.

concepts.name: Retrospective Memory Deficit
concepts.description: Impaired recall of past events, measured via self-report. Found to be more prevalent in night types with poor sleep-wake alignment.

methods.name: Cross-Sectional Survey
methods.description: A study design collecting data from participants at a single time point to examine associations between variables. Used here to assess relationships among chronotype, sleep, time perception, and memory.

methods.name: rMEQ Assessment
methods.description: The reduced Morningness-Eveningness Questionnaire (rMEQ) is used to classify participants' chronotype. It consists of 5 items measuring preference for morning or evening activity.

methods.name: MSQ Measurement
methods.description: The Mini Sleep Questionnaire (MSQ) evaluates sleep-wake quality through self-reported items on sleep duration, latency, and disturbances. Used to assess sleep quality and arousal issues.

methods.name: PRMQ Evaluation
methods.description: The Prospective and Retrospective Memory Questionnaire (PRMQ) measures self-reported memory performance across both domains. Used as the primary outcome variable.

methods.name: STQ Instrument
methods.description: The Subjective Time Questionnaire (STQ) assesses dimensions of time perception, including time pressure, time expansion, and boredom. Used to capture subjective time experience.

methods.name: Pearson Correlation
methods.description: A statistical method used to measure the linear relationship between two continuous variables. Applied to examine associations between chronotype, sleep quality, time perception, and memory.

methods.name: Multiple Linear Regression
methods.description: A statistical technique used to model the relationship between one dependent variable and multiple independent variables. Used to identify predictors of memory performance.

methods.name: Structural Equation Modeling
methods.description: A multivariate statistical method used to test complex causal models, including direct and indirect effects. Applied here to test the mediation model linking chronotype to memory via arousal and time perception.

methods.name: Mediation Analysis
methods.description: A statistical approach to determine whether an intermediate variable explains the relationship between an independent and dependent variable. Used to test the proposed pathway from chronotype to memory via time perception.

methods.name: Self-Report Data Collection
methods.description: A method relying on participants' personal accounts of behavior, experiences, and perceptions. Used for all measures in the study, including sleep habits and time experience.

methods.name: Demographic Questionnaire
methods.description: A tool used to collect basic participant information such as age, gender, and work schedule. Used to describe the sample and assess potential confounders.

methods.name: Variable Standardization
methods.description: A preprocessing step where variables are transformed to have a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1. Likely applied to ensure comparability in regression and SEM models.

methods.name: Model Fit Assessment
methods.description: Evaluation of how well a structural equation model fits the observed data using indices like CFI, TLI, RMSEA. Used to validate the proposed mediation model.

methods.name: Path Coefficient Estimation
methods.description: A technique in SEM to estimate the strength and direction of relationships between latent and observed variables. Used to quantify the indirect effects in the mediation model.

methods.name: Confidence Interval Estimation
methods.description: A method to estimate the range within which a population parameter lies, used to assess the significance of indirect effects in mediation analysis.

methods.name: Data Screening
methods.description: A preliminary step to check for missing values, outliers, and normality assumptions before analysis. Likely performed to ensure data quality.

methods.name: Variable Selection
methods.description: The process of choosing which predictors to include in regression models based on theoretical relevance and statistical significance.

methods.name: Descriptive Statistics
methods.description: Summarization of sample characteristics (e.g., mean age, gender distribution) and variable distributions. Used to characterize the participant sample.

methods.name: Internal Consistency Check
methods.description: Assessment of reliability (e.g., Cronbach’s alpha) for multi-item scales like PRMQ and STQ to ensure measurement consistency.
